"Not only are you not going to talk to me about your child,
me talking about my loss and child is not on the table either."
You know? So I think gratitude, in some ways, is healing for people,
translation.ko: 그래서 감사함은 어떻게 보면 사람들을 치유해요

translation.en: and we don't think about it that way.
The second thing that I learned
that changed me as well is this idea that when I said,
"Tell me about the grief, the longing, the loss,"
translation.ko: 제가 '슬픔, 그리움, 상실에 대해 얘기해 보세요'라고 하면

translation.en: and they said the thing that surprised them the most
was how they missed the ordinary moments
more than anything else.
That they missed the simple, ordinary things
that they never really took notice of when they were happening.
translation.ko: 당시에는 알아채지 못했던 것이 그립다고 했어요

translation.en: One woman told me, "I used to get these crazy texts from my mom
translation.ko: 한 여성분은 제게 그랬죠 '엄마가 휴대폰 사용법을 잘 몰라'

translation.en: because she never quite learned how to use her phone.
And I was like, 'Man, learn how to use your phone, Mom, then text me.'
translation.ko: '저는 엄마한테 사용법을 배우고 문자하라고 짜증 냈거든요'

translation.en: And now I would kill for a text from my mom.
I wouldn't care, you know, how many emojis were in it.
Just something from my mom, but she's gone now."
translation.ko: '그냥 엄마의 뭐라도 좋은데 지금은 안 계시죠'

translation.en: Or someone--
translation.ko: 또, 암으로 아이가 죽은 부부가 있었어요

translation.en: A couple whose child had died of cancer, a four-year-old.
translation.ko: 또, 암으로 아이가 죽은 부부가 있었어요 아이는 4살이었죠

translation.en: And they said, you know, "We used to get on him all the time and say,
'Man, stop slamming the screen door.'"
This was his, like-- This was his signature move, you know.
Just... [imitates door slamming]
And he said, "Sometimes me and my husband just stand at the back door
and just slam it for five or ten minutes, just to hear it."
translation.ko: 문이 쾅 닫히는 소리를 5-10번쯤 그냥 듣는대요

translation.en: You know, there's these-- And for all of us,
I think, for me, the lesson was, and you can take it if it fits...
I get so busy sometimes chasing the extraordinary moments
translation.ko: 전 가끔 비범한 순간들을 좇느라 너무 바빠서

translation.en: that I don't pay attention to the ordinary moments.
The moments that, if taken away, I would miss more than anything.
You know? My daughter has this really interesting thing.
She was probably... ten, maybe nine at the time,
and I picked her up from school in Houston, where we live,
translation.ko: 저희 사는 휴스턴에 있는 학교에서 애를 데리고 와서

translation.en: and we went to Hermann Park, and we were on one of those paddle boats.
I brought some old bread, and we were feeding the ducks.
I looked over and she was like this...
I was like, "Are you okay?" And she goes...
And finally, she said, "Yeah, I'm good." And I was like, "What are you doing?"
translation.ko: 한참 뒤에 '네, 괜찮아요' 뭐 하냐고 물었더니

translation.en: And she goes, "I was making a picture memory."
And I said, "What's a picture memory?" And she said, "Sometimes,
translation.ko: 사진 기억이 뭐냐고 물었죠 애가 하는 말이 '가끔 뭔가 너무 좋아서 감사할 때'

translation.en: when I'm really grateful, and things are just amazing,
translation.ko: 애가 하는 말이 '가끔 뭔가 너무 좋아서 감사할 때'

translation.en: I close my eyes and take a picture memory,
so when I feel lonely or things are hard, I can remember it."
translation.ko: '그럼 외롭거나 힘들 때 다시 떠올릴 수 있어요'

translation.en: You know, I think the picture memory is a lot better than our phone.
translation.ko: 사진 기억이 휴대폰보다 훨씬 나은 것 같아요

translation.en: You know, I think taking a moment and just committing to just that feeling.
translation.ko: 잠시 시간을 가지고 그 감정을 잘 느껴 보는 거예요

translation.en: What were we in, in that moment?
The next thing which is really hard for me, and I'll be honest,
translation.ko: 그다음은 저한테 정말 어려운 건데 솔직하게 말할게요

translation.en: is sometimes just do the joyful thing for the hell of it.
translation.ko: 그냥 기쁜 일을 하기가 너무 어려워요

translation.en: Just choose joy sometimes.
Just choose a thing that seems frivolous and fun
translation.ko: 시시하고 재밌어 보이는 것을 선택하는 거예요

translation.en: and has no ROI or payoff or upside.
Just do the joyful thing.
You know? And, you know, Stuart Brown, who studies play,
defines play as time spent without purpose.
translation.ko: 놀이의 정의가 목적 없이 보내는 시간이라고 해요

translation.en: -Like, I call that an anxiety attack. -[audience laughs]
Like-- Like, I-- I have a hard time doing that,
just choosing joy.
But Charlie, who's 13 now,
last year when he was in sixth grade, he came to me one day and he said,
translation.ko: 작년에 6학년일 때 하루는 제게 와서 그러더군요

translation.en: "I really need to up my grade in this class.
I really want to do it." I said, "Your grade's fine."
translation.ko: '꼭 잘 받고 싶어요' 저는 지금도 괜찮다고 했더니

translation.en: And he said, "No, I-- I think I really want to try." And I said, "Okay."
translation.ko: 아니라며 정말 노력해 보고 싶다고 했어요 그러라고 했죠

translation.en: A week later he comes home and said, "We got a huge project.
translation.ko: 일주일 뒤에 와서는 큰 과제가 있대요

translation.en: It's a big one." And I said, "Okay."
He said, "I was just gonna do it tomorrow morning before school,
translation.ko: 학교 가기 전에 내일 아침에 하려고 했는데

translation.en: but maybe I should just dig in."
And I said, "Okay. Let's do it."
And he said, "It's an art project." I'm like, "Oh, my God.
I have an art and craft supply addiction issue.
So I was like, "Let's go to the craft closet." Um...
And so he had to make a gladiator helmet out of, like, paper.
translation.ko: 찰리는 종이로 검투사 투구을 만들어야 했죠

translation.en: And so he starts making it, and I'm kinda watching.
Every now and then I have an idea, and he's like, "Eh," which is good.
translation.ko: 제가 아이디어를 줄 때마다 마다했죠, 괜찮아요

translation.en: And he's like, "You know, you're allowed to write something on it if you want to.
Should I take a chance and write something on it?
I have a funny idea, but it's kinda weird."
translation.ko: 웃기긴 한데 좀 이상한 생각이 났다면서요

translation.en: And I was like, "Take a chance."
So he writes on it, and he shows it to me,
translation.ko: 찰리가 그 위에 뭔가 쓰더니 저한테 보여 줬어요

translation.en: and his gladiator helmet says, "I run with scissors."
translation.ko: 종이 투구에 이렇게 써 있었죠 '나는 가위질 투사다'

translation.en: -[audience laughs] -And I think it's really funny, right?
So he takes it to school, and I'm like, "How'd it go?"
translation.ko: 학교에 가져 가고 어떻게 됐냐고 물었더니

translation.en: And he's like, "Yeah, I think it was pretty good."
The next day he comes home, and he goes, "Oh, my God.
I won first place.
The best gladiator helmet in sixth grade."
And I was like, "Oh, my God, Charlie.
Effort and you took a chance.
Like, effort and taking a chance doesn't always pay off,
but I don't see anything, really,
that pays off without effort or taking a chance,
so there you go." And he goes,
"She said I could have points added to my final grade,
translation.ko: '선생님께서 최종 점수에 점수를 더할 수도 있고'

translation.en: or, like, a secret treasure."
And I was like, "Oh, how many points are you getting added to your grade?"
translation.ko: 저는 물었죠 '그래서 몇 점이나 더 받아?'

translation.en: He goes...
-"What? I picked the secret treasure." -[audience laughs]
"Yes, that's good.
Right on!" It was like a Pokémon pencil.
I was like, "What?
Secret treasure?" So now every now and then, I'm like,
"I could do this and it could get me here, or I could just pick the secret treasure."
translation.ko: '이걸 하면 이렇게 될 수도 있지만 비밀의 보물을 주울 수도 있지'

translation.en: The joy, right? Just the joy.
Work is another place where vulnerability gives birth to really important things.
translation.ko: 직장은 취약성이 정말 중요한 것을 낳는 또 다른 곳이에요

translation.en: Empathy, trust.
Look...
people call me all the time and say,
"Can you come talk to our leadership team?"
I spend about 90% of my time now doing leadership work.
translation.ko: 요즘 제 시간의 90%는 리더십 강연에 써요

translation.en: "Can you come talk to our team?"
"What do you want me to talk about?" "Anything but vulnerability and shame."
I'm like, "No, I'm not you." They're like--
translation.ko: 전 그건 불가능하다고 하죠 제가 제일 좋아하는 일화가 있어요

translation.en: This is my favorite one. Someone said, "Well...
translation.ko: 제가 제일 좋아하는 일화가 있어요 누가 '4분기 수입'이라고 하길래

translation.en: fourth-quarter earnings."
I was like, "I don't give a shit about your fourth-quarter earnings."
Like, I'm like, "What am I gonna talk to you about?"
They're like,
"We have a huge creativity and innovation problem."
I'm like, "But you don't want to talk about vulnerability?"
No vulnerability, no creativity.
No tolerance for failure, no innovation.
It is that simple.
If you're not willing to fail, you can't innovate.
translation.ko: 기꺼이 실패하지 않으면 혁신할 수 없어요

translation.en: If you're not willing to build a vulnerable culture,
you can't create.
It's just that simple.
Inclusivity, equity, diversity.
We're in the middle of really important movements right now,
translation.ko: 지금 정말 중요한 운동들이 일어나고 있어요

translation.en: movements that I hope will change the world.
Black Lives Matter, Me Too, Time's Up.
-These are-- These are big... -[audience applauds]
These are big movements.
Trans Lives Matter. These are movements that matter,
and these are movements that have the potential to change things.
What happens is, every organization I go into right now, they say,
translation.ko: 요즘 제가 들어가는 조직마다 이렇게 말해요

translation.en: "We don't know how to have these conversations.
They're incredibly uncomfortable.
We're afraid we're gonna say the wrong thing.
We're afraid that what I say won't match my heart.
I'll be taken the wrong way.
People will make assumptions."
And so, I think there's a very clear answer here, which is,
translation.ko: 여기에 분명한 답이 있는 것 같아요

translation.en: first, to not have the conversations because they make you uncomfortable
translation.ko: 먼저 불편해서 대화를 안 한다는 게

translation.en: is the definition of privilege.
Your comfort is not at the center of this discussion.
translation.ko: 이 대화에서 중요한 건 당신의 편안함이 아니에요

translation.en: Like, that is not how this works.
It just doesn't work that way.
Of course you're going to get your ass handed to you in these conversations.
translation.ko: 물론 이런 대화를 하면 엄청나게 욕을 보겠죠

translation.en: And the whiter, straighter, Christian,
majority culture you are, the more mistakes you're gonna make.
translation.ko: 다수의 문화에 속할수록 실수하기 더 쉽죠

translation.en: It's not a question about whether you have a bias or not,
it's what biases do you have, and how many, and how bad, and how deep?
translation.ko: 어떤 편견인지 얼마나 많고 얼마나 심한지가 문제죠

translation.en: That's going to happen.
That's what we sign up for when we have these conversations.
translation.ko: 이런 대화를 할 때 그런 것도 감수하는 거예요

translation.en: That's how it works. And then you listen,
translation.ko: 그런 식으로 되는 거죠 그리고 듣고

translation.en: and you learn,
and you don't hold the people accountable.
You know, the people who are targeted
by racism and homophobia, and heterosexism, and gender bias
translation.ko: 이성애주의, 성에 대한 편견으로 공격당한 사람들에겐

translation.en: are not responsible... for initiating these conversations
translation.ko: 먼저 나서서 이런 대화의 장을 마련해야 할

translation.en: and building the tables where they should be happening.
-[audience applauds] -That's not-- That's not how this works.
We have to be able to choose courage over comfort,
translation.ko: 편안함보다 용기를 선택할 수 있어야 해요

translation.en: and we have to say, "Look...
I don't know that I'm gonna nail this, but I'm gonna try
'cause what I'm sure as hell not gonna do is stay quiet."
That's what we can't do.
And so, yeah, you're gonna make a lot of mistakes.
Yeah, it's gonna be uncomfortable.
Yeah, you're gonna learn about blind spots that you didn't even know you had.
translation.ko: 본인한테 있는 줄도 몰랐던 맹점을 알게 될 거예요

translation.en: And then you're gonna be grateful for that moment
and take learning it...
into your own hands, not make other people responsible for teaching it,
translation.ko: 스스로 나서서 배우고 그걸 다른 사람한테 가르치라고 맡기지 말아야죠

translation.en: and that's how we move forward.
But if you think there's gonna be real conversation in this country
translation.ko: 그런데 이 나라 혹은 회사나 조직에서

translation.en: or in companies or organizations
around equity and-- and diversity and inclusivity...
while you remain comfortable,
that is not gonna happen.
And it shouldn't happen.
So when we build cultures at work,
where there is zero tolerance for vulnerability,
where perfectionism and armor are rewarded and necessary,
you can't have these conversations. They're not productive.
translation.ko: 이런 대화를 할 수 없어요 생산적이지 않아요

translation.en: How many of you think, tomorrow, if I had a magic wand
and I could wave it at where you work-- it's your office--
and tomorrow morning when you walked in,
everyone in that office had the capacity for difficult, productive conversation,
translation.ko: 사무실 사람 모두가 어렵고 생산적인 대화를 할 능력이 생기는

translation.en: how many of you think things would change overnight?
translation.ko: 이런 변화가 하룻밤 만에 일어날 거라 생각하시는 분?

translation.en: If everyone could have really hard conversations?
We can't have them. You know what we end up doing?
translation.ko: 그럴 수가 없죠 결국 어떻게 되게요?

translation.en: We end up talking about people instead of talking to people.
translation.ko: 사람들과 이야기하는 게 아니라 사람들에 대해 이야기하게 돼요

translation.en: And it's really--
It's toxic. It just takes over culture.
Giving feedback, receiving feedback, problem-solving, ethical decision-making...
translation.ko: 피드백을 주고받고 문제 해결하고 윤리적인 결정을 하고...

translation.en: These are all born of vulnerability.
I understand that work seems like a hard place to be vulnerable,
translation.ko: 직장은 취약성을 보여 주기에 어려운 곳인 거 알아요

translation.en: but we spend more than half of our lives at work,
translation.ko: 하지만 우리 삶의 절반 이상을 직장에서 보내죠

translation.en: and I've never met a single person or interviewed a single person in 20 years
translation.ko: 20년 동안 인터뷰를 하면서 단 한 사람도

translation.en: that had a joyful, wholehearted life that was miserable at work.
translation.ko: 직장에서 비참했지만 즐겁게 살았단 사람은 없었어요

translation.en: That stuff will eat you alive.
And we all have a responsibility to show up
and bring our whole hearts and our whole selves to work
and lean in to the tough conversations.
Brave leaders are never silent around hard things.
translation.ko: 용감한 리더들은 힘든 주제 앞에 절대 침묵하지 않아요

translation.en: Our job is to excavate the unsaid.
translation.ko: 우리는 말하지 못한 것을 드러내야 해요

translation.en: What is the thing that's not being said?
And that requires courage and vulnerability.
People ask, "Where do I start with vulnerability?"
And the best place to start is dispelling the myths.
translation.ko: 잘못된 인식을 없애는 게 최고의 출발점이에요

translation.en: So myth one: Vulnerability is weakness.
I've spent a lot of time
evangelizing around this, and here's the thing.
I've cut it down to one question.
And here's the question:
Vulnerability...
is-- the definition of it, from the data-- uncertainty, risk, emotional exposure.
translation.ko: 자료에 의하면 취약성의 정의는 불확실성, 위험성 감정의 노출이에요

translation.en: So vulnerability is the feeling that we get when we feel uncertain,
translation.ko: 우리가 불확실하거나 위험하거나 감정이 드러났을 때

translation.en: at risk, or emotionally exposed.
So I was doing work with special forces
maybe a year ago now, and I asked a question.
Could anyone, any one of the troops in this audience,
give me an example of courage from their life
translation.ko: 동료의 삶에서 용기를 목격한 적이 있으면

translation.en: or something they witnessed in a colleague's life.
A single example of courage
that did not require uncertainty, risk, and emotional exposure,
translation.ko: 감정의 노출이 필요 없었던 용기를 본 적 있냐고 했더니

translation.en: and there was just silence.
And I waited, and it seemed like a long time, and finally...
translation.ko: 저는 기다렸죠 한참 시간이 지나고 마침내

translation.en: a young man stood up and said, "Three tours, ma'am.
translation.ko: 젊은 분이 일어나서 그랬죠 '3번 파병을 갔다 왔는데요'

translation.en: There is no courage without vulnerability."
And so I would ask y'all, in here, give me a single example of courage
translation.ko: 여러분께 물어볼게요 본인의 삶이나 타인의 삶에서

translation.en: in your life or that you've witnessed in someone else's.
A single example of courage
that did not require uncertainty, risk, or emotional exposure.
translation.ko: 불확실성, 위험, 감정의 노출이 없었던 경우 말이에요

translation.en: I don't think you can.
There is no courage without vulnerability.
Yet, how many were raised to believe that courage is an important value?
translation.ko: 용기는 중요한 덕목이고 살면서 용감해야 한다고

translation.en: That you should be brave with your life? Show of hands.
translation.ko: 배우면서 크신 분 손 들어 보세요

translation.en: How many of you were raised to believe that vulnerability is weakness?
Here's the rub. Be brave, but never put yourself out there.
translation.ko: 이게 문제죠 '용감해라 그러나 너를 드러내지 마라'

translation.en: We've gotta dispel the myth, right?
Number two: "I don't do vulnerability."
translation.ko: 두 번째 '나는 취약한 행동을 하지 않는다'

translation.en: Yes, you do.
Anyone here manage to live to this point in your life
translation.ko: 여기 계신 분 중에 지금까지 살아오면서

translation.en: without uncertainty, risk, or emotional exposure?
translation.ko: 불확실성, 위험, 감정 노출 없이 살아오신 분?

translation.en: No. We do vulnerability. And here's the thing.
You only have two options. There's-- You only have two options.
You do vulnerability knowingly,
-or vulnerability does you. -[audience laughs]
Vulnerability shows up, and you-- and if you don't know, just go home...
translation.ko: 취약성이 앞에 나타났는데 그걸 모르면 집에 가서

translation.en: and say, "Hey, do you think I do vulnerability well?"
to someone you love, and then step back a couple steps...
-[audience laughs] -...and take in the truth.
You do vulnerability, knowingly or unknowingly.
And here's the thing. Here's why we need it.
Man, it is so much easier to cause pain than feel pain.
translation.ko: 고통을 느끼는 것보다 고통을 일으키는 게 훨씬 쉬워요

translation.en: And people are taking their pain
and they're working it out on other people.
And when you don't acknowledge your vulnerability,
you work your shit out on other people.
Stop working your shit out on other people.
Right? Stop.
It's okay if you've got crazy stuff going on. Join the club.
translation.ko: 미칠 것 같아도 괜찮아요 저희와 함께해요

translation.en: Like we all do.
The difference is, don't offload your hard stuff on other people.
translation.ko: 차이점은 자기 힘든 점을 타인한테 떠넘기지 않는 거예요

translation.en: Three: "I can go it alone." This was my favorite.
translation.ko: 셋, '혼자 할 수 있다' 제가 좋아하는 거예요

translation.en: One time after a talk, a guy came up to me and goes,
translation.ko: 하루는 강연 후에 한 남자분이 저한테 와서

translation.en: "I'm gonna try it.
I'm gonna try vulnerability...
...but I'm gonna try it by myself.
And I'm gonna see how it goes,
and then I'm gonna try it with other people."
And I was like,
"I-- I don't think that's gonna work. Like, I don't know what that means."
And he's like,
"I'm just gonna...
do it alone for a while." And I was like, "All right, you get back to me."
translation.ko: 당분간 혼자서 해 본대요 그래서 나중에 다시 오라고 했죠

translation.en: We can't go it alone. We're neurobiologically hardwired
translation.ko: 혼자 할 수는 없어요 우리는 신경 생물학적으로 타인과 연결돼 있어요

translation.en: for connection with other people.
translation.ko: 우리는 신경 생물학적으로 타인과 연결돼 있어요

translation.en: In the absence of connection, love, and belonging,
there is always suffering.
You can't go it alone.
If you could, I would have found a way by now.
As an introvert...
and somebody who loves humanity but is más o menos on people...
translation.ko: 제가 내향적이고 인간성을 사랑하지만 사람이라면 적당히 하고 싶거든요

translation.en: -[audience laughs] -...I would have found a way.
Number four: "You can engineer the uncertainty and discomfort
out of vulnerability."
I work a lot with tech companies in Silicon Valley and around the world,
translation.ko: 실리콘 밸리에 기술 회사들과 일을 많이 해요 전 세계에서

translation.en: and they really want to engineer
the uncomfortable part out of vulnerability,
translation.ko: 취약성에서 불편한 부분을 다뤄 보려 하죠

translation.en: to the point where one of them said,
"We're thinking about an algorithm...
-[audience laughs] -...that could actually help you predict
translation.ko: 언제 취약해도 되는지 예측할 때 도움이 되는 알고리듬을

translation.en: when it's okay to be vulnerable with other people."
translation.ko: 언제 취약해도 되는지 예측할 때 도움이 되는 알고리듬을 만들려고 했어요

translation.en: And I was like, "The minute it becomes comfortable, it's no longer vulnerability.
translation.ko: 저는 편안해지는 순간 취약한 게 아니라고 말해요

translation.en: Call it whatever you want, but don't use that name on your app."
translation.ko: 그걸 뭐라고 부르든 앱에 그 이름을 쓰진 말라고 했죠

translation.en: "Trust comes before vulnerability."
This is a hard one, right?
Like, do I trust you then I'm vulnerable with you?
translation.ko: 제가 여러분을 먼저 믿고 취약성을 보일까요?

translation.en: Or am I vulnerable with you, and then I learn to trust you?
translation.ko: 여러분에게 취약성을 보인 후 신뢰를 얻게 될까요?

translation.en: And the answer is "yes and..."
It's a slow stacking over time of vulnerability and trust.
translation.ko: 취약성과 신뢰는 오랜 시간 천천히 쌓아 가는 거예요

translation.en: We don't go out with, like, you know, the big guns, and like,
"Nice to meet you. I'm Brené. Here's my darkest secret.
translation.ko: '반갑습니다, 전 브레네예요 저의 가장 어두운 면은 이거예요'

translation.en: Can I trust you forever?"
We start with little things, and we build over time,
translation.ko: 작은 것부터 시작해서 시간을 두고 쌓아 가요

translation.en: and the more I share with you, and the more you honor that sharing.
translation.ko: 내가 더 많이 공유할수록 상대는 공유를 더 특별하게 여기죠

translation.en: But here's the thing...
you share with people who've earned the right to hear your story.
translation.ko: 당신의 이야기를 들을 자격이 충분한 사람에게 이야기하세요

translation.en: Your story is a privilege to hear.
You share it with people who've earned the right to hear it.
translation.ko: 들을 권리가 있는 사람들과 이야기를 나누세요

translation.en: You don't share it... just because.
Vulnerability minus boundaries: not vulnerability.
translation.ko: 경계가 빠진 취약성은 취약한 게 아니에요

translation.en: Last: "Vulnerability is disclosure."
This goes back to the boundary thing.
Live Tweeting your bikini wax: not vulnerability.
translation.ko: 비키니 왁싱을 라이브로 트위팅하는 건 취약성이 아니에요

translation.en: Sharing the intimate details of your divorce and your pain on Facebook
translation.ko: 이혼의 상세한 내용과 고통을 페이스북에 올려서

translation.en: for your kids to read, who are reeling as well:
translation.ko: 마찬가지로 힘든 자녀들한테 읽게 하는 건

translation.en: not vulnerability.
Again, vulnerability minus boundaries is not vulnerability,
and you don't measure vulnerability by the amount of disclosure.
translation.ko: 얼마나 드러냈느냐에 따라 취약성을 재지 않아요

translation.en: You measure it by the amount of courage to show up and be seen
translation.ko: 결과를 통제할 수 없을 때 얼마나 용기를 내어

translation.en: when you can't control the outcome. Does that make sense?
translation.ko: 자신을 드러냈는지에 따라 재는 거예요, 아시겠죠?

translation.en: Okay, we're gonna end with a story.
So, Ellen, my daughter, decides to try swim team, and she tries--
translation.ko: 제 딸 엘런이 수영팀에 들어가기로 했어요 그래서 1년 동안 수영팀에서 활동하기로 했죠

translation.en: She decides to try a year-round swim team,
which is a big commitment 'cause we have a rule in our house
translation.ko: 큰 결심이에요 저희 집에선 운동을 할 거면

translation.en: that if you try a sport, you've gotta finish the season.
So she-- I'm picking her up one day from swim team practice,
translation.ko: 하루는 수영팀 연습 후에 딸을 데리러 갔는데

translation.en: and she's-- she's young. She's probably...
maybe fifth grade, and I can see-- How many of you have had this experience?
translation.ko: 애가 어렸어요 아마 5학년쯤 됐을 거예요 제가 보니 딱 알겠더라고요 이런 경험 해 보신 분?

translation.en: I can see from her silhouette in front of me
when I'm still eight cars behind that she's crying.
translation.ko: 앞에 차가 8대나 있어도 울고 있단 걸 알았죠

translation.en: Like, I can tell by the way she's holding her body that things are not okay.
translation.ko: 몸을 가누고 있는 자세를 보니 괜찮지 않다는 걸 알았어요

translation.en: So I get up next to her. She gets in the car, and she's crying, and I said,
translation.ko: 애한테 다가가니 애가 차에 타서 울더군요 제가 그랬죠

translation.en: "What's wrong? What happened? What's going on?" She goes,
"I have to swim the 100 breaststroke in the meet this weekend."
And I'm thinking to myself, "No! Not the 100 breaststroke!"
And I was like, "Man, that's a tough race."
And she goes, "Mom, you know." And I was like,
"That's a tough race, girl." And-- And here's the thing.
translation.ko: 애가 '엄마, 아시네요' 저는 '힘든 시합이겠다' 문제는요, 평영이 어려워요

translation.en: Breaststroke is a hard stroke.
It's like, one day it just comes together, and you get it.
translation.ko: 하다 보면 어느 날 제대로 하게 되죠

translation.en: And like, the arms work with the frog legs, and it just happens.
translation.ko: 개구리 다리와 팔 동작이 어느 순간 맞아져요

translation.en: But until then, while you're doing it, you actually don't propel forward.
translation.ko: 그때까지는 아무리 해도 앞으로 나가지를 못해요

translation.en: Like, when you don't--
You kinda go forward, then you come back, and then you go--
And so, 100 yards is a long way for non-propelling.
I'm dying on the inside 'cause, you know, like,
I wasn't a great swimmer either, and I had those moments,
translation.ko: 저도 수영을 잘 못해서 그런 순간이 있었거든요

translation.en: and, like, what I want to say is, "Well, run away and don't worry about it."
translation.ko: 전 애한테 걱정 말고 그만두라고 하고 싶었어요

translation.en: But I'm trying to be, like, the parent that--
translation.ko: 하지만 용감한 부모가 되려고 노력하고 있었죠

translation.en: you know, the brave parent. I'm like, "It's a tough thing.
translation.ko: 하지만 용감한 부모가 되려고 노력하고 있었죠 '힘들겠다'

translation.en: Let's get home, get you showered. Let's talk about it.
Let's talk about it with your dad."
And so we get home,
and she goes upstairs to take a shower, and she comes down, and...
Steve's home, and we sit down for dinner, and, you know, she starts crying again,
translation.ko: 스티브와 다 함께 저녁 먹으려고 앉았는데 애가 또 울기 시작했어요

translation.en: and she explains everything to her dad, and, you know, he's like,
translation.ko: 모든 걸 아빠한테 설명했죠 스티브가 그러더군요 '코치님을 존중해야지'

translation.en: "Well, I think we respect your coach, and it's your coach's call,
and I think you're gonna have to swim if that's the race you're put in."
And, you know, very much we aligned on messaging,
just like the books say.
And so she-- she starts crying. And she goes up after dinner and I'm like,
translation.ko: 그랬더니 애가 울었죠 밥 먹고 올라간 후에

translation.en: [grunts] "Curse you, Steve," and, you know, like, "You should have got her out of this!" Um...
translation.ko: 제가 '스티브, 당신 진짜 미워! 애를 그만두게 했어야지'

translation.en: Then she comes back down real quick, and she goes, "So you're sure?"
-I'm like, "We're sure. This is--" -[audience laughs]
Yeah. So, but-- But I said, "Don't you think, Steve,
that she could take it up with her coach?
If you don't want to swim it, take it up with your coach."
She comes home the next day, and she said, "Coach Jason says I'm in.
translation.ko: 다음 날 집에 와서 코치 선생님이 하라고 했대요

translation.en: A hundred yards-- 100 yards breaststroke. I'm doing it."
I said, "That's tough." Starts crying again,
and she said, "My friend said
that I could scratch my heat."
And so what that means is, in swim meets, they'll call an event,
translation.ko: 무슨 뜻이냐면 수영 대회에서 종목을 불러요

translation.en: like girls' 100 breaststroke,
then they start calling heat. Heat one, heat two, heat three.
And swim meets run like this,
and a lot of the time, swimmers miss their call.
And so, that's considered scratching the heat. So her friend said,
"Just don't show up when they call your heat."
Which I know all about because I scratched some heats in my day.
translation.ko: 저도 잘 알죠 한때 저도 좀 해 봤으니까요

translation.en: Only one or two, but for big races.
And I said, "You-- You could do that." And she goes, "I could?"
translation.ko: 제가 그럴 수도 있겠다고 했죠 그래도 되냐고 되묻더군요

translation.en: And I said, "You definitely could do that. I think it's a choice.
You'll have to take that up with your coach if you don't show up on the blocks for, you know, for your race."
translation.ko: '그런데 출발대에 안 나타날 거면 코치님과 이야기해야 할 거야'

translation.en: And she said, "Will I get grounded here?"
And Steve's like,
"No. No. I mean, that's your choice, Ellen, you know."
translation.ko: 그게 아니라 선택하면 된다고 얘기해 줬어요

translation.en: And then she just starts sobbing. She said, "I'll never win this race."
translation.ko: 그랬더니 흐느끼면서 절대 우승 못 할 거라고 하더군요

translation.en: And I said, "You will never win this race."
translation.ko: 제가 그랬죠 '이 시합에서 절대 우승 못 해'

translation.en: I said, "That is for sure," and I said, "But you know what?
Sometimes winning is not coming in first.
translation.ko: '꼭 1등으로 들어오는 것만이 우승은 아닐 때도 있어'

translation.en: Sometimes winning is doing the really brave thing.
Maybe winning for you is just coming off the block and getting wet.
translation.ko: '너한테는 출발대에서 뛰어들어 물에 들어가는 게' '우승일지도 몰라'

translation.en: Maybe that's winning for you.
Maybe that's what a win looks like."
She goes,
"So if I scratch the heat, I don't get grounded?"
-[audience laughs] -[Brené] And I said, "Yes. Right. Yeah."
So, it's meet day. We're there.
They call the heat. No-- We don't see Ellen.
And then all of a sudden, at the last minute,
she pops up on block number eight, you know,
so Steve and I situate ourselves at the end of the thing,
and then the gun goes off, and there they go.
And I can see her, and she is struggling, and she's trying,
and I can see, like, right kind of like at 75 yards,
she checks the lanes, you know, 'cause she's in a far lane.
translation.ko: 다른 레인을 확인하더군요 멀리 떨어진 레인에서

translation.en: She checks the lanes,
and she gets this look on her face like, "I'm ahead."
And-- And you can see, you know, like,
"Oh, my God. I'm ahead!"
And then you can see, as she's finishing the final 25,
that she understands that there are no other swimmers in the pool,
translation.ko: 풀에 남은 선수가 없다는 걸 이해했죠

translation.en: that she's been lapped so badly
that the whole field is out of the pool,
and that, in fact, when she finishes,
not only are all the other girls from her heat out of the pool,
translation.ko: 자기랑 같이 시작한 애들은 다 나갔을 뿐만 아니라

translation.en: the next heat is on the blocks, ready to go in,
translation.ko: 다음 차례 애들이 출발대 위에 준비하고 있었죠

translation.en: and people are just kinda watching but not watching.
translation.ko: 보는 사람도 있고 안 보는 사람도 있고 그랬어요

translation.en: And I can see her struggling to get out of the pool
'cause that's-- that was a big race.
When you're not going anywhere for that long, it's a lot of work.
translation.ko: 그렇게 오래 수영하면 꼼짝을 못 하잖아요

translation.en: I mean, it-- it's hard.
And I can see her, and she stops by her coach.
He kind of bends down on one knee, and you can see her talking to him,
and he's doing this, and she's just shaking her head.
And she didn't have her goggles off,
and I know she didn't have her goggles off 'cause I know she's crying.
And then she comes over and--
You know, and her dad-- And, you know, me and Steve, we were like mama and papa Phelps during this thing.
translation.ko: 저랑 스티브는 내내 펠프스 부모님처럼 응원했죠

translation.en: It was like she was going for the Olympic trial.
We were like, "Pull! Pull!" Like, you know?
There's no one in the water but Ellen, and people are just like,
"Wrap it up. Pull, whatever, just, like--"
And she comes over, and she pulls her goggles off, and she's just like--
Just, I think, ashamed and tired and exhausted.
And she said, "Can I say a cuss word?"
And I was like, "Oh, hell, yes, you can say a cuss word."
translation.ko: 제가 당연히 한마디 해도 된다고 했죠

translation.en: And she goes, "That sucked."
[Brené] And I said,
-"That really did suck." -[audience laughs]
I said, "That sucked."
And then she stopped for a minute, and she was looking down, and she goes,
translation.ko: 잠시 가만히 있더니 고개를 숙이고는 그래요

translation.en: "But I was brave, and I won."
-[audience] Ah! [applauds] -You know?
And...
Yeah.
And, to me, she was brave, and she won.
Here's the thing. I'm not gonna bullshit you.
Vulnerability is hard, and it's scary, and it feels dangerous,
translation.ko: 취약하단 건 어려워요 무섭고 위험하게 느껴지죠

translation.en: but it's not as hard, scary, or dangerous
as getting to the end of our lives and having to ask ourselves,
translation.ko: 이런 자문을 할 만큼 어렵고 무섭고 위험하진 않아요

translation.en: "What if I would have shown up?
What if I would have said I love you? What if I would have come off the blocks?"
Show up,
be seen, answer the call to courage,
translation.ko: 본인을 드러내세요 나를 바꾸는 용기에 응답하세요

translation.en: and come off the blocks 'cause you're worth it.
translation.ko: 출발대에서 뛰어드세요 여러분은 그럴 가치가 있습니다

translation.en: You're worth being brave. Thank y'all.
translation.ko: 여러분은 용감해질 자격이 있어요 모두 감사합니다

translation.en: [Brené] Thank you.
Thank you! Thank y'all!
Good night!
